text: well good afternoon everybody my name is Shane Hawthorne I'm from Amazon Web Services region

commercial cloud service but what I'm here to talk to you about today is a really interesting new service that I'm
actually the general manager for the name of the services AWS ground station
and like I said I'm Shayne Hawthorn I'm the general manager of that program and wanted to first off start out this talk
by saying even though I'll be honest with you it's very hard to see into the crowd because of the glare of the lights
how many folks here actually work with satellites space operations or ground stations or have before in the past okay
so that's a good norming thing there it this will be interesting and I'm gonna
really be trying to talk to you guys in a way so that everybody can sort of get
and understand how they could capitalize on AWS ground station and use it in their businesses and in your
applications and just to give you a little bit of a heads-up on how I would like to run the show as well I'm going
to leave a little bit of time at the end so that we can have a couple of questions and answers in case people
were interested in how the service actually works so thank you all for coming so a little background I've been
at Amazon Web Services for about two years and actually about one and three-quarter almost to the two-year
mark before that I actually worked in the US government in the Air Force as well as in a company called The MITRE
corporation where I did a whole lot of different things with satellites I've done ground station operations I've
worked on launch vehicles I've integrated satellites onto launch vehicles and built satellites and launch
them into orbit so this is a project that is incredibly passionate to me
I own this entire service working for region services to deliver it to you and
it's it's like been my life for the last year so really excited that you guys are
here so first off what is a ground station a ground station is basically
a surface-based antenna system that is put into the ground so that you can
allow satellites to communicate with the earth and typically you use that service
so that you're able to communicate with the satellite just like you would do with hardware or infrastructure you want
to monitor the satellites state of health you're gonna be checking on it making sure that it's executing its
commands properly watching for anomalies that data all comes down to your ground station and then you monitor it and you
keep track of the satellites health if you need to change things for example maybe one of your solar arrays motors
aren't working or something like that you need to point it at the Sun better you change over to an alternate motor that would be a command that you uplink
to the satellite now if you had satellites that were actually taking photos of the earth or something like
that you would also be sending commands up to that satellite to tell it what you wanted to do in temporal space so you
tell it hey at this time as you're over this part of the earth I want you to take a picture of here those are all the up links that go up to the ground
stations and then the last thing that the ground station does coming down to it is the the product or the payload
data the mission data that the satellite collects that a company actually wants to make money off of sharing with others
making decisions from that mission download comes in to these ground station antennas as well so you have to
have the ability to uplink commands and downlink the health of the satellite and downlink that mission data that allows
you to do your mission with the satellite so location is a real key driver of where you put ground stations
and it can present a lot of challenges to our users so the reason why that's
such an important issue is if you have a number of satellites in what's called a sun-synchronous or a polar orbit that
means that they tend to go over the Earth's poles and there's a couple of different reasons for observing the
earth that you do that but that results in the fact that those types of satellites usually like to have their
ground stations up at the top of the earth because they go over them a lot and that allows them to communicate many
times in a day other satellites that are maybe orbiting around the equator of the earth in the mid latitudes of the earth
they would like their ground stations to be in those latitudes of the earth because that way they could go over them
and they have frequent opportunities to download the data that's what we mean about accessibility can the satellite
get to that ground station or can that ground station make a link with the satellite and then availability do you
have enough ground stations to take care of all the satellites that you're actually using so the location
drives both of those because if you're in Nepal you need a lot more antennas because a lot of the satellites are
going to go over the poles of the earth at the same time availability is difficult in that case so ground station
markets situation it's just like Andy was talking about yesterday during our launch which I hope a number of you guys
were able to see basically we'd been listening to our customers and they were
being presented with a number of challenges and they had come up with ideas of you know if you were able to
use the AWS network with our really robust regions and availability zones
and the way that we build everything around the earth to give strong reliability and resiliency even to
operations it's kind of a perfectly made situation to help address some of these challenges so the challenges that these
customers wanted us to help them fix with AWS ground station was first off a
lot of times if you build your own satellite you're thinking of a new mission you're faced with I'm going to
have to maybe consider that I have to build my own entire ground network so that means I'm going to have to go
through the work of finding the land for these antennas locating where the
antennas should go making sure that I have good site angles and visibility around the entire ground station
location so that I can see these satellites as they're coming up over the horizon and it's not like I put it over
here in the middle of the Venetian and it's covered by buildings that I can't see the satellite except for when it's
directly over my head so they end up having to do all this work to find the ground station buy the land put the
ground stations into that area and then comes the building of the antenna itself they're expensive
they often need a lot of different workloads and business process logic in order to make them work
you have to provide the infrastructure they need to be connected to the network and you have to operate them and
maintain them and sustain them so building your own ground station could be a real heavy lift especially if
you're only thinking about a two to five satellite maybe demonstration project where you want to develop an idea and
maybe get venture capitalists interested in your new project and you don't want to sink all of this money into a ground
station network at the beginning the other alternative that creates a challenge for these customers is the
need to maybe lease these ground stations and what that means is there's a number of great places around the
world who offer antennas as a service but not as a web service where you can
come in and you can actually lease or rent time on the antenna but that also brings a strong tail of sustainment and
logistics that you have to take care of where you have to install your own hardware you have to pay for the time
that you actually use the satellite and you oftentimes have to pay for mmm you
have to pay for a long-term contract in order to get the prices that you want so
you're sort of bought in strongly at that point and that can also limit a company in addition to that in a typical
scalability situation satellites are also faced with the need to maintain
enough ground stations and enough downlink capability to take care of peak
periods of operation when they might really be busy they're taking lots of images for example after a hurricane or
fires or to support certain news events suddenly they've got to get a lot of data down so they need to make sure that
they have enough ground stations to do that but for during normal operations they might end up being in the situation
where they're only using their ground stations two thirty forty percent utilization and all that other time it's
not being used and they're paying for that and they're operating it and sustaining it that is a key challenge
another one is satellite scheduling once you get into kind of a contention situation you might be using ground
stations that a lot of other people are using or you've kind of built your own so you're trying to have the bare
minimum that you can do to take care of your peak well if you have the situation where a number of your satellite
come over these ground stations at the same time they can actually start to interact with each other or interfere
with each other's ability to downlink data at the same time so that's what we mean by you can have a challenge in
scheduling your satellites and then finally and one of the things that we're really excited about AWS ground station
offering to meet these challenges is you oftentimes don't have compute in storage
or the ability to apply cloud services or AWS services to your data the moment
it comes off of the satellite and this is something that a lot of our customers want because it's all about speed today
everybody wants to collect data they want to task their satellites to find things and they want to get that data
back on the ground as rapidly as they can because that allows them to get their product to market quicker and
they're able to monetize and keep on producing things that their customers want
so these challenges summed up from a customer point of view if you look at the point of view of government
customers whom we want to be able to provide services to and in education from the point of view of universities
or university affiliated research centers all the way down to high schools putting up shoebox satellites all of
these people are putting in small satellites up into orbit today and then we have businesses out there who are
strong players in the market today there's a number of Earth imagery systems for example a good partner of
ours is digital globe we've been working with black sky and we've been working with capella and these are different
satellite systems that want to take pictures of or image the earth with different types of phenomenology like
radars or optical systems like our cameras or different frequencies like a
digital globe can actually see an infrared so that it can see fires through clouds so those customers want to get their
data to the ground and so they have the challenge that the ground like I told you is expensive to build and maintain
it can require some very high capital expenditure and so as a result that
capex is required to go into their ground station network and they don't get to use that to build satellites or
build payloads or instruments or sensors that are monitoring the earth to make money for
them and help them to keep their business going that capex can now be traded for variable expense now they can
use AWS ground station and maybe save that capex to do other things or just
save the money completely also in today's day the the challenge from some
of these distributed ground networks because of those locations I told you about which can be remote and austere
they end up having latency and it can take a little bit longer to get that data back to their processing center or
to the cloud than they would like it to by putting our AWS ground station
antennas in close proximity to our data centers that enables them to have very
low latency from receiving the data into the antenna using digital signal
processing equipment to actually demodulate it the same way the modem does behind your TV at home to get your
cable signal and turn it into internet and then allow you to get that data into AWS so that you can actually start using
our services and features on that information the latency can be very low and we're also going to provide capacity
on demand to meet our customers needs so by allowing customers to reserve time
ahead of time on the system and schedule minutes of contact for the satellites that will allow us to start planning
capacity and we're actually building antennas ahead of time and we're actually building our ground stations
with expansion in mind so that as we grow our customer base and as their
needs increase we'll be delivering a very high level of SLA so that we can
not have conflicts while they're operating and then finally in a typical AWS fashion AWS ground station is going
to have a transparent pricing in order to address the challenges of opaque
pricing which we see in the market a lot today where when people go to lease or go to buy they're not sharing that data
you don't typically have the economies of scale of buying all the equipment and as a result you really don't know what
the market price is typically and you are thus a little bit of a disadvantage with this system you're
actually going to be able to look on a console and you'll be able to see the price and you can plan for it and you
can use the same types of calculators that you use for your other AWS services to compute out how much you're going to
pay to use our service as well so the customers told us that they had some
strong requirements in addition to the challenges that they wanted us to meet for them these requirements were first
that they didn't want a capex commitment they wanted to be able to come in on demand and be able to use us and scale
us as required and that's a really interesting thing for a lot of satellite and space customers because by in
allowing them to have on-demand scalability they can now plan for a
system with say 60 satellites but they know that they're going to put up three or four demonstrator satellites at the
beginning of their programs life and they don't want to go they're gonna have to build a complete ground station
network for those four satellites but they want to learn something from those satellites so they're going to put up
the first four they're gonna experiment and then while they're building the next fifty six of those satellites the ground
stations are sort of sitting there fallow waiting to do something being maintained costing them money in our
world they're going to be able their requirement was we want you to make this on-demand and scalable the same way that
we can get ec2 they also said had a strong requirement for minimal data
latency actually into the realm of milliseconds of time between receiving
data on the antenna and being able to get that data into our V PC so that we
could then stream it into the customers V PC they told us they wanted direct access to the data center so that they
could apply AWS services to their data now that gives a lot of opportunities to
a satellite customer you can apply machine learning you can apply things like recognition for doing pattern
matching and looking at the images you can do lots of different types of new algorithms that you can try out and then
if you don't like them you can modify them and they're not built in and deployed around the world they're in the cloud and then finally they wanted like
I told you earlier simple and transparent pricing so as Andy launched yesterday we
listened to our customers we listened to their challenges and their requirements that they wanted us to provide and we've
created and are offering in preview mode right now AWS ground station and what AWS ground
station is is a fully managed self-service global ground station as a
service which we also you'll hear many people call GCS or a ground station as a service and that's going to give our
customers the ability to easily and effectively control their satellites by up linking commands and monitoring their
data in the cloud it's going to allow them to downlink and ingest that data in AWS and it's going to allow them to
process that data right there in AWS cloud and that is going to enable them
to innovate and share their data with a number of other collaborators and customers and then use the AWS services
to take care of processing that information so let me give you a little
overview now of how AWS ground station will work first off we got the customers that I told you about earlier the
government the higher education and businesses they're now going to have no ground station infrastructure
commitments you'll be able to log on to the AWS console it's it's open today you're at it was launched yesterday when
we made the announcement and we'll have an onboarding process for how we bring people in to come and get their accounts
so that they can actually operate satellites and we do that on purpose because we want to provide assurance to
satellite operators that we're not just letting anybody walk in and start trying to communicate with their satellite it's
the same way you would feel if someone was driving down the road of your neighborhood and was trying to see if their garage door opener would work on
your garage door you don't want somebody to be seen if they can communicate with your satellite at the same time so as
part of our onboarding process as you go to the console you're actually going to go through a simple two-factor
verification process where we'll look at data and we'll work with you so that we can validate that the right people want
to communicate with the right satellites and then they'll be able to get in and you're going to either be able to literally reserve minutes on-demand
which means at that point in time you could actually schedule the next available contact after you figure it
out if satellite is going to be in view of a specific ground station or it's going to give you the ability to reserve minutes
for a long period into the future so that you can get a discount on reserved
minutes the same way that with ec2 you could get a discount with reserved instances so it's going to give a level
of flexibility and planning so that we can manage our capacity and it'll benefit the customer because you'll
you'll be able to find lower cost per minute for your up links and down links
by using a reserved minute model so it'll be usage based you'll pay per
minute instead of per data which is really neat because that means a lot of satellites of today are getting bigger
they're collecting more data they're down linking more data we want that data to come to AWS we want you to be able to
use our services to process and make it better so we wanted to make it a per minute charge so that you could take
advantage of that and not be limited by your data rate or your bandwidth and trying to cut it down we want you to
make it as big as your mission requires and then we're gonna provide you self-service scheduling this is kind of
an important facet to go into there's a number of great programs there's a number of great satellite systems around
the world that do what's called mission planning and mission planning is when you'll figure out what you want to do
with your satellite for example I want to take pictures of the forest fires in California so you need to plan that I
know when my satellites are going to be over these parts of the earth I know that I want to take photos at certain
times certain places and then I know where the ground stations are so that I can command the satellite and I can
downlink data that's mission planning we want to help foster a strong market
place in a community where people build mission planning they build satellite processing modems software definable
radio applications on AWS to do all of those functions and we're going to be
providing what we consider a simple reservation service where your mission planning system could interact with AWS
ground station via api's and and then be able to in a machine-to-machine manner
schedule the time that your mission planning system told you that you needed to do certain activities on your
spacecraft that way you can control those aspects of your satellite and we
can be providing you the scheduled contact times that you need to meet your
satellites needs we are also going to have the ability for simpler smaller satellite systems to simply use our
manual GUI console go into the AWS console navigate yourself down to the
new space and satellite I'm trying I'm
sorry I'm just trying to think of the right word here for you but the category so that you that's where a ws ground
station will be located and then you could simply go to our console and you'd be able to login and once you'd been on

finally you're going to have direct access to AWS services our infrastructure the network and the

stations in other regions from that one account it's a global service that we're

stomp after talking about that is first and foremost it's going to allow you to innovate with

to process data bring data down from the satellite share it with other customers
make decisions and then distribute it as a product over AWS you're also going to
be able to save up to 80% on your ground station costs over building your own ground station network they would

anything which is going to happen very rarely quite frankly because we're really buying such good in tennis we'll

as many people call it any industry t TNC tracking telemetry and control and
you're gonna be able to schedule off of the API or off of our GUI console you're
gonna be able to uplink and downlink data both narrowband data which if you want to think about it this way a good
way to think comparatively as narrowband data which is about 54 megahertz of
bandwidth is like 4G and then you can do wideband data which is about up to about
a gigabit per se Canora gigahertz a bandwidth is like 5g so we provide two levels of data rate in
order to meet the needs of different types of customers and then you're going to be able to pay per use and you're
gonna get that low latency rapid data processing that I talked about with you earlier so how do we do it
this is the cool thing we've been working on this for a while our software development team and our hardware team

2019 in the AWS ground station VPC
you're going to have all the functionality that we use to operate and run AWS ground station for you the
customer you're going to have the onboarding functionality that I talked about earlier going in through the
console and then a method of communicating back and forth with you so that you can get through the onboard

so that we can actually configure the ground station to fit each satellite operators configuration for each of
their contacts so we have to be able to do that very rapidly so that we can do a contact with one satellite and then in a

come up and then be able to take care of them as well because as I told you we really want to be able to
provide a low contingent or no contingent service to our customers so
orchestration has been key and it's been a lot of work now if you're going to run any kind of orbital system communicating
with satellites you have to have a good orbital propagation capability you need to know where the satellites are you
need to give our customers the ability to load what we call ephemeris or satellite location data into the system
so that we can predict where you're going to be and tell you if the satellite is going to be in view of a
ground station so that you can make a good reservation and you can feel comfortable and guaranteed that you're
going to be able to talk to the satellite when you planned on it that's the realm of the propagation a location
sync services and then after that you're now kind of in the realm of receiving
the data from the satellite that's why I would point you to the bottom three
right-hand side of the satellite VPC first off the scheduler has now told you
where you could talk to your satellite based on orbital mechanics and where your satellite is you made a reservation
it goes into the scheduling system and now we know that you actually have this
slot when when a satellite comes above the horizon we'll actually be waiting for it and we'll be waiting to receive
the data as the satellite starts to try to communicate with the ground station that's when we actually have a narrow
band or a wideband as I told you a high data-rate or a low data rate capability to
downlink that data into a software-defined radio and receiver and then we also have software controlled
modems in the pedestal of each of our ground station antennas so that we can
actually configure the receiver and the modems to be exactly like the hardware that you built your satellite to work
with and so in that case you're then able to demodulate the data decode it frame sync it make it work the way that
you're used to it working with your own system and you can then pass it in to a front-end processor and the front-end
processor is basically what can take the raw data and turn that into objects and files that you use to make information
from for your system so that you're able to then turn those into the things that
you actually trying to collect data for so the raw data from the satellite sensors now becomes either radio frequency
intercepts of figuring out where a signal is and where it was going and what angle it was pointed at or taking
pictures of the earth you're turning that data into an actual image that people are used to looking at or you can
get into more esoteric things like radar data or multispectral data where you actually can analyze pixel by pixel what
you're looking at the front end processor is what then delivers that data to you in a usable format another
neat thing that our software definable radios and modems can do is we actually can configure them as well to act as
what's called a digitizer the digitizer allows you to give yourself an even
higher level of surety that the data that we took off of the satellite is as close to the original data as possible
by leaving it in an analog form that can travel over an IP network so we do that
by putting a data into what's called vitae 49 which is a standard for radio frequency or RF data over IP and we have
the ability to now allow you once we reach general availability to send that data over the IP network back to the
region where you're actually processing your data and you could store it and you can leave it in RF you could even
connect it to another digitizer and convert it back into analog data if you wanted to process your data in analog so
it gives you a good amount of frequent flexibility to process your data you can either put it out in what's called
baseband which is a very load you know look relatively speaking it's a little
bit of data that you don't have to work as hard to move around the network or you can leave it in RF over IP which is
a very big amount of data but it gives you the level of fidelity that a lot of customers want now that data then goes
into the customers V PC we can actually stream it into the customers V PC and
now the customer has two options if you used our V PC to do the demodulation and
they're receiving and they're processing and then went through the front end processor to turn it into baseband you
could simply move that data now into your V PC and start saving it into s
three buckets or EBS or you could even start processing it right there in your V PC literally a millisecond or a second
after it came off of the antenna you can start making things with your data in the region where the data landed or you
could then move it across the network to wherever you are and you could do the same thing or if you wanted to leave it
in RF over IP like I talked about earlier you can now have your customer VPC full of your own bring your own
capabilities you could write your own modems you could write your own software definable radios you could write your own front
end processors or you could run front end processors from a number of our
collaborating partners who are going to be putting services out there into AWS marketplace to offer modems and offer
software receivers that you could buy or use by the minute and and put into your
V PC to process data and then in addition you could have your own monitor and control system that's monitoring the
telemetry in the data coming off of our system so that you can see what's happening while you're working with your
satellite and you can monitor your own system you can run your satellite and you can have command and control
software so that you can literally write your commands and send them back up to the satellite from the your V PC during
the contact and to prove that this actually works we've actually done this
if you guys go out and look at digital Globes blog that they actually have a really cool example of where during one
of our test cases we were actually able to command a satellite from the ground
station region where it was coming down in Oregon to take a picture of the antennas where we were working and
testing with digital globe people posed out there in the form of an Amazon smile
and then after the satellite took the picture they ran back into the control area of the datacenter to see if the

get it into an s3 bucket where you could do something with it in less than a minute with a system like this and it's

thing about it is you could build your satellite you can test it with ec2 you

when you're not doing anything with the satellites you're not paying for it and now you can use the same thing to test

the ground station that's connected to AWS so it'll give you the ability to do

you could actually start to make decisions from some of the data there was streaming into your V PC that can
open up a lot of really cool use cases as well and what I'm really excited about with that is that I'm a space guy
I come to this with a space guy bias so I kind of think of the way that I've always done it of the way we've done it
I'm really excited that we're going to get a lot of innovative thinkers people who are going to be able to use space
